Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Faddeev approach to nuclear reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nuclear Science is tasked with answering questions such as: (i) How did matter come into being and how does it evolve? (ii) How does subatomic matter organize itself and what phenomena emerge? (iii) How can the knowledge and technology progress provided by nuclear physics best be used to benefit society? Providing answers to these questions depends on a detailed theoretical understanding of nuclear reactions, a field in which current approaches are either outdated or limited to a small number of applications. In this larger context, this project will focus on the theoretical study of deuteron-induced reactions. Due to the short lifetimes involving exotic nuclei, direct neutron capture measurements of relevance to the origin of the heavy elements are often not possible. Indirect techniques like deuteron induced reactions are a common tool to extract the relevant astrophysical rates. These reactions are part of ongoing experimental programs at radioactive beam facilities, as well as programs at future facilities such as the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB). As such, this project will provide theoretical support to challenging experimental programs and will provide a unique training opportunity for graduate students and post-doctoral fellows.

A reliable reaction theory is critical for the understanding the data produced at experimental programs using (d,p) reactions. From a theoretical perspective, (d,p) reactions are attractive because the scattering can be reduced to an effective three-body problem. One of the most challenging aspects of solving the three-body problems for nuclear reactions is posed by the repulsive Coulomb interaction. While for light nuclei the momentum-space Faddeev equations can be treated by screening the Coulomb force, a similar approach is difficult to implement for heavy systems. Indeed, for most of the new exotic nuclei to be produced at FRIB, currently available computational methods are not adequate. This project will address this critical need and provide an implementation of an exact Faddeev method for the three-body nuclear reaction problem, in which the Coulomb force will be treated without screening.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivated by learning about the properties of nuclei and extracting crucial reaction rates for astrophysics and other applications, researchers perform nuclear reactions in laboratories across the world. One class of reactions involves impinging a deuteron on the target of interest. From a theory standpoint, these reactions are most often approximated by a three-body problem: neutron+proton+target. 

 

Over decades, much work has gone into establishing the methods used to solve the three-body scattering problem. The exact equations where introduced by Faddeev but there are difficulties when the particles involved have charge because the Coulomb force has infinite range. A group in Lisbon introduced a technique that involves screening the Coulomb force. While this technique has been fruitful for reaction with light nuclei, it breaks down when applied to heavy nuclei. 

 

When the equations are rewritten in a different basis (the Coulomb basis) and the interactions are made separable, one no longer needs to use screening of the Coulomb interaction. This project consisted on a collaboration between Ohio University (PI Elster) and Michigan State University (PI Nunes), with the objective of implementing this new approach and demonstrating is validity.

 

First the collaboration focused on implementing the problem for bound states, which is easier than scattering conditions. Calculations using this new framework were applied to 6Li as neutron+proton+4He. Benchmarks with the traditional method showed that the new method converges to the correct answer with good accuracy.

 

Next the collaboration moved to implementing the formalism for scattering. Benchmarks of the new method for the scattering of deuterons on 4He demonstrates, for a variety of different quantities, that the new method reproduces the screening method of the Lisbon group. 

 

This project supported the postdoc Jin Lei at OU and the graduate student Alaina Ross (MSU). This collaborative effort was leveraged with an MSU contribution that supported the postdoc Linda Hlophe MSU. 

 

The suite of codes resulting from this project can be made publicly available upon request.

 

This project impacts the experimental program at various rare isotope facilities (such as NSF supported NSCL and DOE supported FRIB) that include deuteron induced reaction as part of their scientific programs. It also can impact other fields such as quantum chemistry where three-body problems with charged particles are relevant.
